name: hydrogen production, coal gasification | hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29621/documentation

This process represents the production of 1 kg gaseous hydrogen by coal gasification. This process does not include compression of hydrogen after its production. This dataset does not cover any carbon dioxide capture and storage function. In this process, coal is converted in the gasifier in the presence of steam and oxygen at high temperature, to hydrogen and carbon dioxide.;In the United States of America, about 4% of hydrogen is produced by coal gasification.;Hydrogen is an inorganic substance with a CAS no. : 001333-74-0. It is called 'molecular hydrogen' under IUPAC naming and its molecular formula is: H2. It is gaseous and it has no odour. The substance is modelled as a pure substance. On a consumer level, is used in the following products: fuels and related products, water treatment products. On industrial sites, the substance is used for the manufacture of products in the following sectors: Fuels and fuel additives, functional fluids (closed systems), intermediates, laboratory chemicals, odour agents, oxidizing/reducing agents, processing aids, specific to petroleum production.;This dataset was recontextualised from the Chinese dataset.;References:;Li, J.; Wei, Y-M.; Liu, L.; Li, X.; Yan, R. (2022): The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514.;Wokaun, A., Wilhelm, E., Schenler, W., Simons, A., Bauer, C., Bond, S. (2011): Transition to hydrogen - pathways toward clean transportation. New York: Cambridge University Press.;Muresan M., Cormos C.-C., Agachi P.-S. (2013): Techno-economical assessment of coal and biomass gasification-based hydrogen production supply chain systems, Chemical Engineering Reseach and Design, 91, 1527-1541.;Stiegel G. J., Ramezan M. (2006): Hydrogen from coal gasification: an economical pathway to a sustainable energy future, International Journal of Coal Geology, 65, 173-190.

From the reception of coal at the factory gate.

The activity ends with hydrogen at 25 bar being ready for further processing or transportation at the production site gate.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/352:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains/3520:Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This activity has been copied from an original dataset representing the geography of China and published in 2022. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and not expected to change significantly over time.;;Reference:;Li, J.; Wei, Y-M.; Liu, L.; Li, X.; Yan, R. (2022): The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This activity is a copy of a dataset for coal gasification in China. The material and energy inputs reflect well the production technology and are, therefore, considered to be valid for the chosen geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The coal gasification process can be separated into five subunits: air separation unit (ASU), gasification unit, water-gas shift unit (WGS), acid gas removal unit (AGR) and hydrogen purification unit (pressure swing adsorption, PSA). The majority of gasification technologies are currently based on entrained-flow reactors. The first unit, the air separation unit, is an independent unit which supplies oxygen needed for the gasification process and for the hydrogen sulphide processing by fractional distillation of liquid air. In addition nitrogen used for the transportation of coal into the gasification reactor also provided by the ASU. Before being fed into the gasification reactor, the oxygen and nitrogen are compressed to 48 bar.;In the gasifier, high operating temperatures are required for a satisfying conversion rate. The outlet gas temperature ranges between 1250-1600°C.;The third unit, the water-gas shift step which includes an exothermal reaction aiming on increasing the hydrogen output. The carbon monoxide in the syngas reacts with steam at a temperature ranges between 250-500 °C. For this process, the steam to carbon monoxide ratio is between 2.08 and 3.1, and a carbon monoxide conversion of up to 98% could be attained. Hence, in this process, full water gas shift is assumed and therefore no synthesis gas (mixture of CO and H2) is co-produced, ;Subsequently, the separation of acid gases (carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulphide) is achieved through gas-liquid absorption using an organic solvent. The captured hydrogen sulphide is removed and partially oxidized to sulphur using oxygen from the ASU. Additionally, the carbon dioxide is captured from the sulphur-free gas. The captured species in the rich solvent are then released in the solvent regeneration precess. The cleaned syngas is sent to the the hydrogen purification stage.;Hydrogen purification is mostly done through PSA. The hydrogen purification unit operates on an isothermal cycle, adsorbing at high pressure and desorbing at low pressure. The final hydrogen purity is 99.99% (vol.) and the yield of the process is about 85%. Carbon dioxide is not captured in this modelling, it exits the plant with the flue gas.;References:;Li, J.; Wei, Y-M.; Liu, L.; Li, X.; Yan, R. (2022): The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514.;Wokaun, A., Wilhelm, E., Schenler, W., Simons, A., Bauer, C., Bond, S. (2011): Transition to hydrogen - pathways toward clean transportation. New York: Cambridge University Press.;Muresan M., Cormos C.-C., Agachi P.-S. (2013): Techno-economical assessment of coal and biomass gasification-based hydrogen production supply chain systems, Chemical Engineering Reseach and Design, 91, 1527-1541.;Stiegel G. J., Ramezan M. (2006): Hydrogen from coal gasification: an economical pathway to a sustainable energy future, International Journal of Coal Geology, 65, 173-190.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography CN. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

flow.name: hydrogen, gaseous, low pressure
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description: Input of coal for the production of hydrogen via gasification. This value is deduced from the data provided by Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514". Namely, they reported that the production of 1 kg of hydrogen from coal requires to mine 8.9 kg of coal, which is subsequently treated leading to the wastage of 2.04 kg. An additional 0.089 kg of coal are lost during transport to the hydrogen production facility.

The input amount was calculated via a mathematical relation based on the Co input.

exchanges.description: This value is estimated based on the input of anthracite (hard coal) and an average ash content of 11% to ensure the mass balance and the completeness of the dataset. Besides, the chemical composition of anthracite comprise of around 77% carbon, 6-16% ash, and moister. Some trace elements are also present in the chemical composition of anthracite, such as sulfur − 0.23-1.2%, silica oxide − 2.2-5.4%, alumina − 2%, ferric oxide − 0.4%. Reference: Wypych, George. "Fillers–Origin, chemical composition, properties, and morphology." Handbook of Fillers 4 (266) (2016): 13.

exchanges.description: This value is estimated based on the input of pure water to ensure the mass balance and the completeness of the dataset. Namely, an amount of 10.5 kg pure water input per kg H2 produced was reported by  Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514", while 4.51 kg of steam were also cogenerated. Based on this, a total of 5.99 kg of water were assumed to be sent for treatment.

exchanges.description: Value reported by  Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514" for the production of hydrogen via coal gasification.

Due to the absence of process data for the release of NOx for the production of hydrogen from coal, this exchange was roughly estimated as described below.

In the United States, an amount of 734,000 t of NOx emissions were released in 2022, along with 845,000 t of SO2. Assuming that the release of NOx and SO2 is correlated, this ratio was here used as a rough estimation, to approximate the release in NOx for the production of hydrogen from coal.

References: 
https://www.epa.gov/power-sector/progress-report-emissions-reductions#so2
https://www.epa.gov/power-sector/progress-report-emissions-reductions#nox

Value reported by  Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514" for the production of hydrogen via coal gasification.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. This value is estimated based on the CO2 output of this dataset to ensure the mass balance and the completeness of the dataset. It was assumed that all oxygen in CO2 originates from air.

Methanol used a s asolvent in the acid gas removal system which recovers hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide as separate streams. The Rectisol® process develped by Linde and Lurgi, is a physical acid gas removal process that can purify synthesis gas down to 0.1 ppm total sulfur, including hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and carbonyl sulfide (COS), and carbon dioxide (CO2) in the ppm range. It is also able to remove impurities such as hydrocarbons, ammonia, and hydrogen cyanide, consistent with its origin as a treatment for syngas from the Lurgi gasifier which contains these kinds of impurities.  Value reported by Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514" for the production of hydrogen via coal gasification.

exchanges.description:
Calcualted value, according to the AP-42, CH 8.13: Sulfur Recovery release by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (.gov), available here: https://www3.epa.gov/ttnchie1/ap42/ch08/final/c08s13.pdf, assessed on the 2023-10-09.
Namely, the SO2 emissions are expressed in kg/Mg sulfur recovered, ad is equalt to  ( (100% recovery)/(%recovery) - 1 ) *2000

Proxy for the CoMoO4 used in the catalytic system. A value of 0.67 g of  CoMoO4  per kg H2 was reported by  Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514" for the production of hydrogen via coal gasification. The input amount was calculated via a mathematical relation using the Co atomic mass and the molecular weight of CoMoO4.

exchanges.description: Raw surface water input for steam production, with demineralisation. This value is deduced from the input of pure water for the production of hydrogen via coal gasification. Namely, an amount of 10.5 kg pure water input per kg H2 produced was reported by  Li, J. et al. (2022): "The carbon footprint and cost of coal-based hydrogen production with and without carbon capture and storage technology in China, Journal of Cleaner Production, 362, 132514", while 4.51 kg of steam were also cogenerated. Based on the latter consideration, the total input of deionised water is 5.99 kg.

exchanges.description:
This value is estimated based on the input of limestone (CaCO3) and the set of reaction given below. Besdies, Gypsum (CaSO4.2(H2O)) generated during the Flue Gas Desulfurization (FGD) stage of the hydrogen production plant. Namely, a mixture of limestone and water is used for the flue gas treatment, where the undesired SO2 content of the flue gas is converted to gypsum. At first, the limestone reacts with the SO2 in the flue gas to create insoluble calcium sulfite (CaSO3). Subsequently, the CaSO3 further reacts with oxygen to produce gypsum (CaSO4.2(H2O)).
CaCO3(s) + SO2(g) → CaSO3(s) + CO2(g)
CaSO3(s)+ ½O2(g) + 2H2O(l) → CaSO4·2(H2O)(s)
